Article Title: OpenAI launches GPT 5.2 with advanced capabilities, to compete with Google’s Gemini 3
Article Text:
'Trump Needs Indian Skilled Workers': Expert On Big Tech's AI Bet On India

Coding with GPT 5.2





ChatGPT-maker OpenAI has launched GPT-5.2 artificial intelligence model, days after CEO Sam Altman issued an internal "code red" pausing internal projects and redirecting teams to accelerate development. This comes as a response to Google 's Gemini 3 that was launched last month. Announcing the new model, OpenAI said “We designed GPT‑5.2 to unlock even more economic value for people; it’s better at creating spreadsheets, building presentations, writing code, perceiving images, understanding long contexts, using tools, and handling complex, multi-step projects.”As revealed by the company, the new models is aimed to bring more economic value for users.“GPT‑5.2 Thinking sets a new state-of-the-art score, and is our first model that performs at or above a human expert level. Specifically, GPT‑5.2 Thinking beats or ties top industry professionals on 70.9% of comparisons on GDPval knowledge work tasks, according to expert human judges. These tasks include making presentations, spreadsheets, and other artifacts,” the company said.OpenAI says that GPT‑5.2 Thinking sets a new state of the art of 55.6% on SWE-Bench Pro, a rigorous evaluation of real-world software engineering.Unlike SWE-bench Verified, which only tests Python, SWE-Bench Pro tests four languages and aims to be more contamination-resistant, challenging, diverse, and industrially relevant.On SWE-bench Verified (not plotted), GPT‑5.2 Thinking scored 80%, as claimed by the AI maker. “For everyday professional use, this translates into a model that can more reliably debug production code, implement feature requests, refactor large codebases, and ship fixes end-to-end with less manual intervention,” it said.OpenAI further claims GPT‑5.2 Thinking hallucinates less than GPT‑5.1 Thinking. On a set of de-identified queries from ChatGPT, responses with errors were 30%rel less common. For professionals, this means fewer mistakes when using the model for research, writing, analysis, and decision support—making the model more dependable for everyday knowledge work.
Article Summary: ChatGPT-maker OpenAI has launched GPT-5.2 artificial intelligence model. CEO Sam Altman issued an internal "code red" pausing internal projects and redirecting teams to accelerate development. This comes as a response to Google's Gemini 3 that was launched last month.

Article Title: PhonePe Wealth launches daily SIPs starting at Rs 10
Article Text: PhonePe Wealth has announced the launch of its Daily SIP (Systematic Investment Plan) feature in mutual funds, enabling users to invest as little as ₹10 per day directly through the PhonePe app. The initiative aims to make investing more accessible, habitual, and affordable for millions of Indians, turning everyday savings into long-term wealth creation.The new Daily SIP feature allows investors to commit micro amounts daily, offering flexibility and convenience for individuals with regular cash flows. Users can set up SIPs seamlessly via UPI Autopay, choose from curated funds across equity, gold, and multi-asset categories, and adjust contributions based on their comfort and goals. Importantly, SIPs can be stopped anytime, with invested money continuing to compound.Nilesh D Naik, head of investment products at Share.Market (PhonePe Wealth), said: “With Daily SIPs, we are making investing more habitual for millions of Indians. Even a daily investment of ₹10 encourages disciplined, long-term investing and helps overcome short-term market volatility. Our goal is to simplify investing and help every Indian participate in the country’s growth story.”The Daily SIP feature is expected to empower both first-time investors and seasoned participants, fostering a culture of disciplined, long-term wealth creation.
Article Summary: PhonePe Wealth has announced the launch of its Daily SIP (Systematic Investment Plan) feature in mutual funds. Users can set up SIPs seamlessly via UPI Autopay, choose from curated funds across equity, gold, and multi-asset categories.

Article Title: Waymo recalls over 3,000 vehicles in the US: Here’s why
Article Text:
Waymo responds





Google-parent Alphabet owned electric vehicle maker Waymo has recalled 3,067 of its vehicles in the United States, reports news agency Reuters., The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) said that the recall was done over a software issue which was fixed through an update.As per the report, the EV company had recalled certain vehicles with the 5th generation automated driving systems (ADS) operating with software that caused vehicles to drive past stopped school buses, increasing the risk of a crash, the regulator said.Waymo, as per NHTSA, has updated the software and all impacted vehicles were repaired by November 17 this year.Last week, Waymo announced a recall for its self-driving vehicles after Texas officials said the vehicles illegally passed school buses at least 19 times since the start of the school year. The EV maker then said that a software issue caused its self-driving cars to first slow down or stop for a school bus and then move forward. Waymo further stated that it will keep monitoring the system and roll out more updates if needed.NHTSA opened an investigation into Waymo cars in October this year. It has now asked the company to provide details about the incidents in Texas by January 20, the report said.
Article Summary: Waymo has recalled 3,067 of its vehicles in the United States. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) said that the recall was done over a software issue. Texas officials said the vehicles illegally passed school buses at least 19 times since the start of the school year.

Article Title: Google’s AI team DeepMind announces first ‘automated research lab’
Article Text:
Google DeepMind ‘ automated research lab ’ to offer priority access for British scientists







Google DeepMind has unveiled plans to establish its first “automated research lab” in the United Kingdom, expanding its AI-driven scientific research capabilities. The facility is set to open next year and it will leverage advanced AI and robotics systems to conduct autonomous experiments, with an initial focus on developing novel superconductor materials for medical imaging technology and new semiconductor materials.The announcement of the lab comes as part of a broader partnership between DeepMind – Google’s artificial intelligence division – and the UK government.Under the partnership agreement, British scientists will receive “priority access” to some of the world's most sophisticated AI tools, according to the UK government's announcement. This access is expected to accelerate research and innovation across multiple scientific disciplines, positioning British researchers at the forefront of AI-assisted discovery. Moreover, the potential applications span nuclear fusion research and the deployment of DeepMind's Gemini AI models across government departments and educational institutions throughout the region.“DeepMind serves as the perfect example of what UK-US tech collaboration can deliver—a firm with roots on both sides of the Atlantic backing British innovators to shape the curve of technological progress,” said UK Technology Secretary Liz Kendall in a statement.“This agreement could help to unlock cleaner energy, smarter public services, and new opportunities which will benefit communities up and down the country,” Kendall added.Meanwhile, Demis Hassabis, DeepMind's founder, expressed enthusiasm about the partnership's potential impact.“AI has incredible potential to drive a new era of scientific discovery and improve everyday life. We're excited to deepen our collaboration with the UK government and build on the country's rich heritage of innovation to advance science, strengthen security, and deliver tangible improvements for citizens," Hassabis said.
Article Summary: Google DeepMind to establish its first “automated research lab” in the United Kingdom. The facility is set to open next year and it will leverage advanced AI and robotics systems to conduct autonomous experiments. Initial focus will be on developing novel superconductor materials for medical imaging technology and new semiconductor materials.

Article Title: Just hours before sharing stage with OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, Disney sends 'Cease-and-Desist' letter to Google; says: You have ...
Article Text:

What Disney's letter to Google claims





Disney has announced a multi-billion deal with ChatGPT-maker OpenAI. And interestingly, just hours before OpenAI CEO Sam Altman and Disney CEO Bob Iger announced the deal on big stage, Disney sent a 'Cease-and-Desist' letter to Google claiming that the search giant and its products infringe Disney's copyright on a “massive scale”. The letter says that Google's AI models have generated content resembling characters from Frozen, Deadpool, Star Wars, and others. According to reports in Deadline and Variety, Disney wants Google to stop infringing on its copyrighted works.Disney's notice comes just a day before the company announced its billion-dollar deal with OpenAI, which will allow Sora AI users to create videos using more than 200 characters from Disney, Marvel, Pixar, and Star Wars. The AI-generated videos will also reportedly appear on Disney Plus, too, which CEO Bob Iger teased last month.Disney's letter against Google follows cease-and-desist letters that the company has sent earlier to Meta and Character.AI, as well as litigation Disney filed with NBCUniversal and Warner Bros. Discovery against AI companies Midjourney and Minimax alleging copyright infringement.“Google is intentionally amplifying the scope of its infringement, by making its infringing AI Services available across so many channels to so many consumers, flooding the market with infringing works, and reaping enormous profits and other value from its unlawful, harmful, and damaging exploitation of Disney’s copyrighted works,” says the letter from David Singer, the Jenner & Block attorney representing Disney.“Google operates as a virtual vending machine, capable of reproducing, rendering, and distributing copies of Disney’s valuable library of copyrighted characters and other works on a mass scale. And compounding Google’s blatant infringement, many of the infringing images generated by Google’s AI Services are branded with Google’s Gemini logo, falsely implying that Google’s exploitation of Disney’s intellectual property is authorized and endorsed by Disney,” adds the letter, which Variety has reviewed.In the letter, Disney further claims that Google “has refused to implement any technological measures to mitigate or prevent copyright infringement, even though such measures are readily available and being used by Google’s competitors.”The letter cites models like Veo, Imagen and Nano Banana. It calls on Google to cease further copying and distribution of Disney IP in its AI services, as well as to implement technical measures to “ensure that no further outputs” infringe on the company’s works.
Article Summary: Disney sent a 'Cease-and-Desist' letter to Google claiming that the search giant and its products infringe Disney's copyright on a'massive scale' The letter says that Google's AI models have generated content resembling characters from Frozen, Deadpool, Star Wars, and others.

Article Title: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang on why despite being the CEO of world's most-valuable company, sense of uncertainty and insecurity doesn't leave him
Article Text:
Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang, despite leading his company to a $5 trillion valuation, lives in constant anxiety, a fear rooted in a near-bankruptcy experience. Recent reports of Meta potentially buying Google's AI chips have caused a $250 billion market value drop, validating Huang's long-held belief that the company is always '30 days from going out of business'.

Nvidia Makes History: First Company to Hit $4 Trillion Market Cap

A near-death experience that shaped Huang’s three decades of paranoia

Why Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang 's fears suddenly look prophetic





Despite leading Nvidia to become the first company ever to hit a $5 trillion valuation, CEO Jensen Huang admits he operates in constant anxiety, working every single day including holidays. His fears may be justified—this week alone, Nvidia lost $250 billion in market value after reports emerged that Meta is in advanced talks to buy billions worth of competing chips from Google , threatening the chipmaker's decade-long dominance in AI hardware."The phrase '30 days from going out of business'—I've used for 33 years," Huang revealed on The Joe Rogan Experience podcast. "The feeling doesn't change. The sense of vulnerability, the sense of uncertainty, the sense of insecurity—it doesn't leave you."Huang's anxiety isn't unfounded paranoia—it's scar tissue from survival. In the mid-1990s, Nvidia discovered fatal flaws in its first graphics chip while developing technology for Sega's gaming console. With funds evaporating, Huang flew to Japan for an excruciating conversation: he told Sega's CEO the product wouldn't work and the deal must end, but simultaneously begged for the final $5 million payment to prevent bankruptcy.Remarkably, Sega converted it into an investment, giving Nvidia the lifeline that eventually built a trillion-dollar empire.That near-collapse experience now fuels Huang's relentless schedule. He wakes at 4 a.m. daily to read "several thousand emails," works seven days a week without exception—"including Thanksgiving, Christmas"—and admits he's "always in a state of anxiety." His motivation? "I have a greater drive from not wanting to fail than the drive of wanting to succeed. Failure drives me more than greed."Huang's paranoia might be wisdom. Nvidia made the rare move of issuing a public defense after The Information reported that Meta—planning up to $72 billion in AI spending this year—is negotiating massive purchases of Google's tensor processing units (TPUs). The news triggered a 6% stock plunge, erasing roughly $250 billion in value, while Alphabet shares surged 4%."Nvidia is a generation ahead of the industry—it's the only platform that runs every AI model," the company declared on X, breaking its usual silence on competitors. But Google's latest Gemini 3 AI model, trained entirely on TPUs rather than Nvidia chips, is being hailed by industry leaders as potentially superior. Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff publicly announced he's switching from ChatGPT after three years, calling Gemini 3 the better product.The threat is existential to Nvidia's 90% market share in AI accelerators. If Google captures even a fraction of the hundreds of billions being spent on AI processors—particularly from customers like Meta—it would represent the first serious crack in Nvidia's dominance.Huang's work ethic has infected his family: both his children, Madison and Spencer, now in their thirties, work at Nvidia after joining as interns in 2020 and 2022. "Now we have three people working every day," Huang said.For a CEO who never stopped running scared despite building a $4.5-trillion empire, the market turmoil caused by Google likely only confirmed what he's believed for 33 years: you're always 30 days from going out of business.
Article Summary: Jensen Huang is the CEO of Nvidia, the first company ever to hit a $5 trillion valuation. He wakes at 4 a.m. daily to read "several thousand emails," works seven days a week without exception, including holidays. Recent reports of Meta potentially buying Google's AI chips have caused a $250 billion market value drop, validating Huang's belief that the company is always '30 days from going out of business'

Article Title: E-passport explained: What is it, who can apply, what happens to existing ones and other things to know
Article Text:
What is e-passport

How to apply for e-passport





The Ministry of External Affairs rolled out e-passport service under the Passport Seva Programme (PSP V2.0). With the new system, the government aims to facilitate faster, more secure, and smooth travel for all Indian passport holders. While the existing ones remain valid till their expiry, anyone applying for a passport will get a chip-enabled passport by default, irrespective of whether they apply in India or abroad.As explained by the external affairs ministry in a press release, the e-Passport is a hybrid passport that combines both paper and electronic elements. It features an embedded Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) chip and an antenna, which store and secure the holder’s data in accordance with International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) standards.Critical information printed on the data page is also stored electronically on the chip, enabling enhanced security and authentication, the ministry says. Going forward, all newly issued passports will be e-Passports, while existing non-electronic passports will remain valid until their expiry, it added.As mentioned above, any Indian citizen who is eligible for a regular passport can apply for e-passport.The process of applying for an e-passport is the same as that of applying for a regular passport. Applicants are required to first register on the official Passport Seva portal using their personal details. After completing the registration, they must fill in the online application form carefully and pay the prescribed fee through the available payment options.Once the payment is completed, applicants are required to book an appointment at a nearby Passport Seva Kendra or Post Office Passport Seva Kendra, based on their location and slot availability. On the scheduled date, the applicant must visit the selected centre in person for document verification.During the appointment, biometric details of the applicant are captured. This includes taking fingerprints and a photograph, which are used for identity verification and are later embedded securely into the e-passport’s electronic chip.After the verification process is completed and the application is cleared, the e-passport is printed with the embedded chip that stores the holder’s biometric and personal details. The finished e-passport is then dispatched and delivered to the applicant’s registered residential address through the postal system.
Article Summary: The Ministry of External Affairs rolled out e-passport service under the Passport Seva Programme (PSP V2.0) The new system aims to facilitate faster, more secure, and smooth travel for all Indian passport holders. Anyone applying for a passport will get a chip-enabled passport by default.

Article Title: JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon repeats his earlier warning on AI eliminating jobs, wants employees to focus on skills like ...
Article Text:
AI must be regulated: JPMorgan CEO





Jamie Dimon, CEO of America’s largest bank, JPMorgan Chase CEO has once again warned that artificial intelligence (AI) will eliminate jobs in the long run. Speaking in an interview with Fox News’ Sunday Morning Futures, Dimon urged workers to focus on human skills such as critical thinking, emotional intelligence and communication to stay relevant in the future workforce. He said individuals should build skills that machines cannot easily copy. These include problem-solving, emotional understanding, creativity, and clear communication.Jamie Dimon said that while companies have been cautious about hiring in recent months, this slowdown is not being driven by AI. He also said he does not expect the technology to cause large job losses in the immediate future.“For the most part, AI is going to do great stuff for mankind, like tractors did, like fertilizers did, like vaccines did,” Dimon said during the interview. “You know, maybe one day we’ll be working less hard but having wonderful lives.”At the same time, Jamie Dimon stressed that AI will eventually replace some jobs and that people must prepare for this shift. Notably, this is not the first time Dimon has warned about AI eliminating jobs. He has previously warned that automation will change the nature of work. In November 2025, Dimon said AI could help people in developed countries move toward a much shorter workweek of around three-and-a-half days over the next 20 to 40 years.Dimon also said that AI must be regulated properly to limit its risks, just as earlier technologies were brought under rules to protect society. He said both governments and companies have a shared responsibility to manage the impact of AI on workers.“We—government and we the companies, society—should look at how do we phase it in a way that we don’t damage a lot of people,” he said. He pointed to past examples where factory closures hurt entire towns and said better support could have reduced the damage. “You can retrain people, relocate people, income assistance, early retirement,” he added.While warning about future job losses, Dimon also said AI is already creating new jobs in the short term. He said the growth of AI requires large investments in infrastructure, including construction work and fibre-optic networks, which will generate employment.
Article Summary: Jamie Dimon, CEO of America’s largest bank, JPMorgan Chase CEO has once again warned that artificial intelligence will eliminate jobs in the long run. Dimon urged workers to focus on human skills such as critical thinking, emotional intelligence and communication to stay relevant in the future workforce.

"Through this collaboration with OpenAI we will thoughtfully and responsibly extend the reach of our storytelling through generative AI, while respecting and protecting creators and their works."The reversal follows Disney's aggressive legal stance against AI companies like Midjourney, which it accused of operating a "bottomless pit of plagiarism" in a July lawsuit. Just months after Oracle stock hit historic high, stunning Wall Street, after it inked a $300 billion deal with ChatGPT-maker OpenAI , the company seems to be feeling AI jitters. A smaller player in the cloud market for a long time, Oracle this September staked claim as one of the bigger providers of the rented computing power crucial for generative AI after its tie-up with ChatGPT-creator OpenAI. The same month Oracle raised $18 billion in a jumbo bond sale the same month, one of the largest debt issuances on record in the tech industry. Now, just months later, on December 10, the software giant posted quarterly results that fell short of Wall Street's revenue expectations pulling the stock more than 11% in after-hours trading. The not-so-happy results come after Oracle’s historic stock surge in September that valued the company at $500 billion and made its founder Larry Ellison world's richest man (though only for a day).Oracle shares fell more than 11% in after-hours trading after the company said that it burned roughly $10 billion in the November quarter due to spending on data centers for artificial intelligence customers such as OpenAI. According to a report in The Information, cash burn is unprecedented in Oracle’s history and has prompted the company to borrow heavily for such projects, including an $18 billion bond offering in September.Oracle's five-year credit default swaps, which offer bondholders a hedge against default, have shot to record highs as it borrows heavily for the datacenter buildout. This AI-fueled debt load has Oracle investors on edge.Months after Oracle's $300 billion-plus contract backlog ignited a stock-market frenzy, the enthusiasm has given way to doubts about the company's over-reliance on OpenAI and debt-fueled datacenter buildout. Analysts have expressed concerns that a big portion of Oracle's capital expenditure is tied to OpenAI-related data centers. This has sparked investor worries especially as details are scarce on how OpenAI plans to fund its spending, which total more than $1 trillion by 2030.Oracle's stock has eroded all the gains from the stunning 36% jump on September 10 after it announced the $300 billion deals backlog with OpenAI at its last earnings call, even as shares remain higher by nearly a third for the year. November was the worst month for the company, with stock plunging more than 20%. December has been slightly better, but still way below from its record high.In a note to investors, as reported by Reuters, Bernstein analyst Mark Moerdler said that the $300 billion OpenAI data-center contract gives Oracle "unprecedented single customer revenue exposure". Gil Luria, analyst at D.A. Davidson said, "If OpenAI fails and the contract goes away, Oracle would need to scale back the build out, write off some contracts and start working down the debt, but it would not default. Similarly, if "OpenAI achieves super-intelligence, spends $1.4 trillion, none of us have to ever work again, and Oracle is fine", he added.On its part, to allay some of the investor concerns, Oracle said in October that it expects cloud infrastructure revenue to grow to $166 billion in fiscal 2030 and that fresh bookings were coming in from a range of customers, not just OpenAI. The company also touted a $20 billion new deal with Meta Platforms.

In India, between 800 and 1,000 positions across finance, marketing, HR, and technology were impacted, according to ET.Agarwal further explained that the restructuring happening at Amazon is part of CEO Andy Jassy’s vision to make Amazon the ‘biggest startup’. “To operate that way, we need fewer layers. The workforce reductions are primarily about removing those layers, and we’ll continue to do that because we want to stay lean and move like a startup.At the same time, we’ll keep hiring where we need to,” he told ET.Along with this, Amazon is also urging its employees to use artificial intelligence in order to boost productivity, underscoring how technology and efficiency are central to its future strategy.Last month, Amazon CEO Andy Jassy shared his point of view on the recent Amazon layoffs. Article Title: Walmart’s retiring CEO Doug McMillon once said he never planned to stay long: ‘My first time with Walmart was just to …’
Article Text:
A 40-year rise from hourly worker to Walmart CEO

Walmart CEO on what he plans to do after retiring





Walmart CEO Doug McMillon once said that he never planned to stay longer at the company. McMillion, who plans to retire next year on January 31, was speaking at Duke University’s Fuqua School of Business in 2017 when he said: “My first time with Walmart was just to make money during the summertime to help pay my way through school”. “And I didn’t mean to be there very long at all,” he added.McMillon began his Walmart career in 1984 as a college student, unloading trailers at a warehouse for $6.50 an hour. “My first time with Walmart was just to make money during the summertime to help pay my way through school,” he said at Duke University in 2017. “And I didn’t mean to be there very long at all.”After completing his MBA, he moved into corporate roles and became a fishing-tackle buyer in 1991. Over the next two decades, he held several senior leadership roles before being named CEO in 2014. As chief executive, he led a 2.1-million-strong workforce and earned a $1.5 million annual salary, along with stock and other compensation.McMillon said a key factor in his career growth was taking initiative. “One of the reasons that I got the opportunities that I got was that I would raise my hand when my boss was out of town,” he told Stratechery last year.He said attending meetings on behalf of managers helped him gain visibility and prove he could handle bigger roles. “I then put myself in an environment where I became a low risk promotion because people had already seen me do the job,” he said.During a recent interview with CNBC, McMillon said “I’ve never had a blank calendar, and I’ve now seen what one looks like in a few months, and it’s kind of exciting.”The 59-year-old added that he does not expect to stay idle for long and plans to spend his retirement doing “some combination of business and philanthropic stuff.” He said he will “take a few months” off before deciding on next steps.McMillon said he felt it was the right time to hand over leadership as Walmart moves into what he called a new phase shaped by artificial intelligence. “About a year ago, I really started feeling this next run, you could see what agentic commerce was going to look like, the vision for AI shopping. And I started thinking about everything that needs to happen over the next few years, and it really caused me to think that now was the right time,” he said.Walmart’s US business chief John Furner, who has also spent 30 years at the company, will take over as CEO in the new year. “When you see somebody who is ready to run the next lap better and faster than you, it is time to hand the baton and get out of the way and just cheerlead,” McMillon said.
Article Summary: McMillon began his Walmart career in 1984 as a college student, unloading trailers at a warehouse for $6.50 an hour. Article Title: How Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang's solution for America's 'China chip problem' may not actually work
Article Text:
Nvidia's new location verification software for AI chips faces a critical flaw: it's optional for customers. This voluntary system, meant to prevent advanced chips from reaching restricted nations, relies on smugglers to install monitoring tools, a paradoxical approach. The software, designed for fleet management, lacks enforcement, raising doubts about its effectiveness against illicit chip diversion.

Why an opt-in system can't stop Chip smuggling to China

Nvidia H20 Chips for China: What’s Really Going On?

Smuggling concerns mount as DeepSeek allegations surface





Nvidia's newly announced location verification software for AI chips contains a fundamental flaw that may undermine its stated purpose: it's entirely optional for customers to install. The voluntary system, unveiled alongside President Trump's controversial decision to allow H200 chip sales to China, relies on smugglers and bad actors voluntarily installing monitoring software that would expose their own illicit activities—a paradox that raises serious questions about whether the solution can effectively prevent advanced AI processors from reaching restricted countries.The software, unveiled this week alongside President Trump's approval for Nvidia to sell H200 chips to "approved customers" in China, uses GPU telemetry data and communication latency with Nvidia servers to approximate chip locations. While Nvidia positions it as a fleet management tool for data center operators, it also addresses political pressure to curb illegal diversion of advanced AI processors.But the voluntary nature of the system exposes a critical weakness. Smugglers and bad actors—the very entities the tracking aims to catch—have no incentive to install monitoring software that would reveal their illicit activities. The system requires customers to install a client software agent rather than being embedded as a mandatory hardware feature.Nvidia emphasizes the software has "no kill switch" and provides only "read-only telemetry," meaning the company cannot remotely disable chips or take control of registered systems. While this protects customer autonomy and addresses Chinese cybersecurity concerns about potential backdoors, it also means Nvidia has no enforcement mechanism.The timing is particularly notable given recent smuggling allegations. Multiple reports suggest Chinese AI startup DeepSeek may have trained models using smuggled Nvidia Blackwell chips, though Nvidia says it "hasn't seen any substantiation" of phantom data centers being constructed to deceive the company.The software will first appear on Blackwell-generation chips, which include strengthened "attestation" capabilities to verify hardware and software haven't been altered. Nvidia plans to make the client tooling open-source, providing transparency but also allowing potential circumvention.Critics argue the arrangement prioritizes commercial interests over security. Former Biden national security adviser Jake Sullivan called the decision "nuts," saying it hands China computing capability while they work to develop domestic alternatives.For an opt-in system to work as export control enforcement, it requires voluntary compliance from the very actors it seeks to monitor—a paradox that may render Huang's solution ineffective as anything beyond a legitimate business tool.
Article Summary: N Nvidia's new location verification software for AI chips faces a critical flaw. This voluntary system, meant to prevent advanced chips from reaching restricted nations, relies on smugglers to install monitoring tools. The software, designed for fleet management, lacks enforcement, raising doubts about its effectiveness against illicit chip diversion.

Google secures military contract with security guarantees

Article Title: Explained: What is AI scaling that has divided biggest companies across Silicon Valley; including Google, OpenAI, Microsoft and others
Article Text:
In an ongoing debate among leading AI firms, Google’s DeepMind insists on the necessity of scaling models to reach human-like intelligence. Meanwhile, Meta’s Yann LeCun counters that this method has reached a dead end. With enormous financial investments at play and the quest for artificial general intelligence intensifying, Microsoft aims to pursue a measured compromise.

OpenAI's Master Plan for India

The all-in believers: Why Google and OpenAI still back scaling

The growing backlash: Why some AI experts say scaling has hit a Wall

Microsoft 's middle path: Building in-house while urging caution





Silicon Valley's biggest AI companies are locked in a fundamental disagreement that could determine the future of artificial intelligence: Does making AI models bigger automatically make them smarter, or has the industry reached the limits of this approach? Google DeepMind CEO Demis Hassabis insists AI scaling "must be pushed to the maximum" to reach artificial general intelligence—a version of AI that reasons as well as humans. Meanwhile, Meta's to be departing chief AI scientist Yann LeCun bluntly disagrees: "You cannot just assume that more data and more compute means smarter AI. " The debate has fractured the industry, with billions of dollars and the race to AGI hanging in the balance.AI scaling laws, first outlined in OpenAI 's landmark 2020 paper, rest on a simple premise: feed AI models more data and more computational power, and they will become progressively more intelligent. This principle has driven the current AI boom, fueling massive investments in data centers and infrastructure across the tech industry.For years, it worked. Each new generation of large language models demonstrated remarkable improvements simply by scaling up. But now, cracks are appearing. Reports suggest frontier models like GPT-5 are experiencing diminishing returns during pre-training, raising questions about whether the old formula still holds.Hassabis, whose company recently launched Gemini 3 to acclaim, remains confident that scaling alone could deliver AGI, though he suspects "one or two" other breakthroughs will be needed. At the Axios AI+ Summit in San Francisco, he argued that scaling is minimally "a key component" and potentially "the entirety" of the path to AGI.OpenAI CEO Sam Altman is equally bullish, declaring flatly: "There is no wall." Former Google CEO Eric Schmidt predicts that continued scaling over the next five years could make AI systems 50 to 100 times more powerful than today's models, with each iteration delivering factors of improvement.The industry is betting accordingly. OpenAI and other US tech firms have signed hundred-billion-dollar infrastructure deals. OpenAI president Greg Brockman announced partnerships for custom AI chips, proclaiming "the world needs much more compute."But skeptics are emerging even within finance. JP Morgan CEO Jamie Dimon warned that "the level of uncertainty should be higher in most people's minds," questioning whether these massive investments will pay off.LeCun represents the counter-movement gaining momentum across Silicon Valley. At the National University of Singapore in April, he argued that "most interesting problems scale extremely badly," particularly those involving real-world ambiguity and uncertainty.He's leaving Meta to launch his own startup focused on "world models"—an alternative approach that collects spatial data about the physical world rather than simply processing language. His goal is building AI systems that "understand the physical world, have persistent memory, can reason, and can plan complex action sequences."The technical challenges are mounting. High-quality public data is running out, and building data centers is both environmentally destructive and extraordinarily expensive, with roughly 60 percent of costs going to GPUs that depreciate rapidly.A MIT study published in October added weight to the skeptics' case. Researchers found that efficiency improvements in smaller models could narrow the performance gap with giant models over the next decade, especially for reasoning tasks. "In the next five to 10 years, things are very likely to start narrowing," said MIT professor Neil Thompson.Other industry leaders are voicing doubts. Scale AI CEO Alexandr Wang called scaling "the biggest question in the industry," while Cohere CEO Aidan Gomez termed it the "dumbest" way to improve AI models.Microsoft is attempting to navigate between these extremes. Under AI chief Mustafa Suleyman, the company recently renegotiated its OpenAI partnership to remove restrictions on building its own large-scale models. Microsoft is now constructing an in-house frontier AI lab to compete directly with OpenAI, Google, and Anthropic."Microsoft needs to be self-sufficient in AI," Suleyman told Business Insider, announcing plans to train frontier models "of all scales with our own data and compute at the state-of-the-art level."However, Suleyman emphasizes what he calls "Humanist Superintelligence"—AI that is "carefully calibrated, contextualised, and within limits." He warns against the unchecked "race-to-AGI" mentality: "We can't build superintelligence just for superintelligence's sake. It's not going to be a better world if we lose control of it."He acknowledges this cautious approach may be slower and more expensive than competitors' aggressive methods, estimating it will take "a good year or two" before Microsoft's team produces frontier-grade models. And he admits no one has a reassuring answer to the fundamental question: "How are we going to contain, let alone align, a system that is, by design, intended to keep getting smarter than us?"Interestingly, recent studies suggest current AI models may already be remarkably capable. Research shows GPT-4 outperforming doctors in complex diagnostic cases and matching professional financial analysts in predicting company earnings—raising the question of whether dramatically bigger models are even necessary for many practical applications.As the debate rages, the stakes couldn't be higher. The outcome will determine not just which companies lead AI development, but potentially whether the technology remains under human control. Whether through pure scaling, efficiency innovations, or entirely new architectures, the path forward remains uncertain—and that uncertainty is making even the boldest tech leaders nervous.
Article Summary: Google's Demis Hassabis insists AI scaling "must be pushed to the maximum" to reach artificial general intelligence. Meta's to be departing chief AI scientist Yann LeCun bluntly disagrees: "You cannot just assume that more data and more compute means smarter AI" Microsoft is attempting to navigate between these extremes.

Impact of Charlie Kirk’s murder

Article Title: Not just stakes in 600-plus Chinese companies, Intel CEO Lip-Bu Tan may have more multi-billion dollar deals to haunt him
Article Text:
Why Tan felt need to buy Rivos



Intel defends Tan’s industry ties





When Intel CEO Lip-Bu Tan joined the company earlier this year, his appointment faced scrutiny over his investment in over 600 Chinese tech companies. Now, multi-billion dollar deals linked to the CEO have come under renewed attention after new details emerged about Intel’s attempted bid for AI chip startup Rivos. According to a report by news agency Reuters, Tan was both Intel CEO and chairman of Rivos when the chipmaker explored a deal. The report quotes three people aware of the matter who said that “Tan had pitched Intel’s board on buying Rivos in the summer of 2025, but he had no luck.” The board then told Tan he had a conflict in representing both Rivos’ interests and Intel’s, and he lacked a strategy on artificial intelligence (AI) to justify a deal.After the board’s response, Tan told one of Intel executives to pitch a new AI plan, leading to partnership talks with Rivos. However, Meta had also expressed interest in buying Rivos, prompting Intel to make an offer.Meta then raised its offer, pushing the deal value to about $4 billion, Reuters report says. Meta announced its acquisition of Rivos in September this year.Since the financials are not public, it is not known how much Intel CEO profited personally as a Rivos shareholder.But Tan’s venture firm later described the outcome as a “successful” one for its investors.The Rivos deal is one of the three instances where Intel pursued deals involving companies in which Tan holds stakes. Since his appointment, Tan has taken direct control of Intel’s investment arm – Intel Capital. Since then, Intel Capital has invested in several companies in which Tan has a stake through his investment vehicles or venture capital firms, which include A&E Investment LLC, Celesta Capital and Walden International, sources told Reuters.A source quoted in the Reuters report said that Tan believed Intel needed to buy Rivos because earlier in-house efforts to enter the AI chip market had failed. The report also quotes an Intel spokesperson who said Tan was “advancing its AI strategy” and “revitalizing its engineering-centric, customer-first culture.”He allegedly pitched Intel’s board on buying the troubled AI computing startup SambaNova , where Tan served as executive chairman. Rationale? “SambaNova also could provide more tech and talent to build AI chips”.Intel hired Tan earlier this year for his long experience as a venture capitalist and his connections across the semiconductor industry. While these ties helped Intel secure a $5 billion investment from Nvidia and a $2 billion investment from SoftBank, the board has been introducing policies requiring Tan to recuse himself from decisions where he may benefit personally. Intel told Reuters that Tan’s network is important for the company’s growth and said it remains committed to strong corporate governance.
Article Summary: Intel CEO Lip-Bu Tan joined the company earlier this year. His appointment faced scrutiny over his investment in over 600 Chinese tech companies. Now, multi- billion dollar deals linked to the CEO have come under renewed attention after new details emerged about Intel’s attempted bid for AI chip startup Rivos.

Article Title: Airtel, Reliance Jio and Vodafone-Idea to WhatsApp, Snapchat and others: Government is 'right' on SIM-binding and seven 'reasons' you are 'wrong'
Article Text:
1. No, SIM-binding will not cause inconvenience to users

2. No, SIM-binding will not cause inconvenience to overseas travellers, including those using single-SIM phones

3. SIM-binding important for the safety of Indian citizens and India

4. SIM-binding follows security requirement of important platforms like DigiLocker and Aadhaar

5. SIM-binding closes critical loopholes in digital communication

6. Concerns about privacy related to SIM-binding are misleading

7. SIM-binding does not disrupt enterprise messaging





Late last month, the Department of Telecommunications (DoT) gave messaging platforms like WhatsApp, Telegram, Signal, and Snapchat 90 days to enforce 'SIM-binding'. With 'SIM-binding' in force, these apps will stop working if users remove SIM card originally used for registration. The directive, that will go into effect starting effective February 2026, also mandates that web versions of these apps log out users every six hours, requiring fresh authentication via QR code.India's biggest telecom body, Cellular Operators Association of India (COAI) -- whose members include Reliance Jio, Airtel and Vodafone Idea -- welcomed the new DoT guidelines and congratulated the government on the same. COAI said that making SIM binding mandatory would keep a reliable link between the user, the number, and the device, which could help reduce spam, fraud calls, and financial scams.However, Broadband India Forum or BIF, which represents major technology companies such as WhatsApp parent Meta, Google and others, has termed 'SIM-binding' guidelines as "problematic". BIF along with Internet and Mobile Association of India, representing Meta and other digital companies have claimed that no feasibility study or consultation was conducted before these directions were issued.Critics question whether 'SIM-binding' will effectively curb fraud, since many scammers already use SIM cards procured through forged or stolen identity documents. IAMI has characterized the amended rules as representing a "clear overreach" with broad implications for digital businesses across fintech, e-commerce, mobility, and social media.Now in a new note, COAI has once again welcomed the recent Indian government's order on SIM-binding that it says keeps in mind the national and citizens’ interests. It further adds that there are some misconceptions being circulated regarding SIM-binding requirements for app-based communication services. COAI's note counters what it terms as "misplaced narrative" on 'SIM-binding':The narrative that SIM-binding will inconvenience users — particularly overseas travellers — is not borne by facts. SIM-binding is already a standard feature in widely used digital authentication systems such as UPI and payment applications, where the SIM only needs to be present and active in the device and does not require active mobile data. The same model can be seamlessly applied to app-based communication, with no disruption to users abroad who can continue using their services through Wi-Fi or a foreign SIM while keeping their Indian SIM in a secondary slot.Some concerns have also risen that SIM-binding may inconvenience international travellers, particularly those using single-SIM devices. It is important to clarify that this is a deliberate and essential security safeguard, to prevent misuse from outside (and within) India and to stop untraceable frauds and scams while restricting international subterfuges intended to defraud Indian subscribers or cause security harm to the country. This ensures that our communication channels are not exploited freely from outside India by fraudsters or non-state actors, who pose a grave threat to national security and citizen safety.Moreover, the subscriber will not be denied Communication App facilities, as the prevailing rules of that country in this respect will apply -- but the Indian recipient will have his Communication App bound to the Indian SIM, thus enhancing security of the individual and the nation.The requirement for time-bound reauthentication, such as a six-hour logout cycle, aligns with best practices for identity-sensitive digital services like Fintech. High-value systems — including banking portals, DigiLocker, Aadhaar and VPNs -- enforce far stricter session expiry norms. Smartphones remain logged in through cryptographic anchoring, while laptops and browsers -- being multi-user and higher-risk — undergo periodic authentication to ensure accountable access. At the same time, the laptop/tablet user will generally be in possession of his mobile phone carrying the SIM and reauthentication every 6 hours would not pose a challenge, but the security benefits will far outweigh any perceived inconvenience to the laptop/tablet user.Critics have also overstated concerns about the value of this government of India order for enhancing security. SIM-binding is a layered defence, strengthening one of the most common and easily exploited vulnerabilities in digital communication. SIM-binding closes important and critical loopholes and is a step in the right direction in the current environment.Concerns about privacy are similarly misplaced. SIM-binding does not require any expanded data collection by App-based communication services and does not create new metadata categories. It simply ensures that the SIM linked to a user’s identity is present during periodic authentication events, mirroring the widely accepted UPI model. This enhances security without intruding on user privacy.Finally, SIM-binding does not disrupt enterprise messaging, CRM systems, APIs or business workflows. It operates purely at the user account level, ensuring that each account is tied to a verified SIM. These enterprise solutions can continue to operate as long as the underlying user accounts — whether customer-facing or automated business numbers — are associated with valid, verified SIMs.There has been a crying need that the users’ app-based communication services are identifiable at all times without violating existing rules on privacy and data, and yet providing traceability and linkage to the TSPs’ (telecom service providers') SIM without degrading the offerings of the communication apps. This is all that has been done by this recent government of India order, which is aimed at protecting the user against frauds and scams, and the country against anti-national elements and it is a welcome step.To conclude, COAI said, "COAI is of the view that SIM-binding is a balanced, privacy-respecting security measure that reinforces digital trust and enhances user protection against Spams and Frauds, without compromising convenience or business operations. SIM-binding is not just a panacea to strengthen national security but also an idea that is long overdue.”
